statement.tex:
%text For what value of k is the following function continuous at $x=2$?
% f(x) = \begin{cases} 2x + 1\, ; x \lt 2 \\ k \, ; x = 2 \\ 3x - 1\, ; x \gt 2 \end{cases}

options.tex: %text For $f(x)$ to be continuous at $x=2$ \[ \quad \lim_{x\to 2^-}f(x) = \lim_{x\to 2^+}f(x) = k \] %

reason.tex:
%text \[ \lim_{x\to 2^-}f(x) = \lim_{x\to 2^+}f(x) \] only ensures that $f(x)$ has a limit at $x = 2$.
But for $f(x)$ to be continuous, there must be \underline\text{no gap at $x=2$}.
And therefore, \[ \quad \lim_{x\to 2^-}f(x) = \lim_{x\to 2^+}f(x) = k \]
%

\begin{align} \lim_{x\to 2^-} f(x) &= \lim_{x\to 2^-}(2x + 1) = 5 \\ \lim_{x\to 2^+} f(x) &= \lim_{x\to 2^+}(3x - 1) = 5 \end{align} %text
Therefore, $k = 5$ for $f(x)$ to be continuous at $x = 2$ %
